item.title: Photos: Hawks announce jersey sponsorship with YMCA
item.description: On Monday, the Hawks announced a jersey patch sponsorship with the YMCA.

media:content.media:description: Collie Hawk, College Park Skyhawk's mascot, and Harry, the Atlanta Hawks mascot celebrate with one of the local YMCA students at the new sponsorship patch unveiling at The Villages at Carver Family YMCA in Atlanta, Georgia, November 20, 2023. (Jamie Spaar for the Atlanta Journal Constitution)

YMCA students create patches for their new jerseys at the new sponsorship patch unveiling at The Villages at Carver Family YMCA in Atlanta, Georgia, November 20, 2023. (Jamie Spaar for the Atlanta Journal Constitution)

YMCA students play basketball with Harry, the Atlanta Hawks mascot, at the new sponsorship patch unveiling at The Villages at Carver Family YMCA in Atlanta, Georgia, November 20, 2023. (Jamie Spaar for the Atlanta Journal Constitution)

Emcee Tigger leads the singing of the YMCA at the new sponsorship patch unveiling at The Villages at Carver Family YMCA in Atlanta, Georgia, November 20, 2023. (Jamie Spaar for the Atlanta Journal Constitution)

(left to right) Trae Young, Landry Fields, Ernie Johnson and Kobe Bufkin share a fireside chat at the new sponsorship patch unveiling at The Villages at Carver Family YMCA in Atlanta, Georgia, November 20, 2023. (Jamie Spaar for the Atlanta Journal Constitution)

Mayor of Atlanta, Andre Dickens, and Ernie Johnson shake hands at the new sponsorship patch unveiling at The Villages at Carver Family YMCA in Atlanta, Georgia, November 20, 2023. (Jamie Spaar for the Atlanta Journal Constitution)

YMCA students write what YMCA means to them at the new sponsorship patch unveiling at The Villages at Carver Family YMCA in Atlanta, Georgia, November 20, 2023. (Jamie Spaar for the Atlanta Journal Constitution)

Tony Ressler, Atlanta Hawks principal owner, speaks to the attendees at the new sponsorship patch unveiling at The Villages at Carver Family YMCA in Atlanta, Georgia, November 20, 2023. (Jamie Spaar for the Atlanta Journal Constitution)

item.title: Photos: Jackets earn ACC win by beating Syracuse
item.description: Photos from the Georgia Tech vs. Syracuse football game on Nov. 18, 2023. The Jackets won 31-22.

media:content.media:description: Georgia Tech head coach Brent Key hugs wide receiver Avery Boyd after Tech won an NCAA college football game against Syracuse in Atlanta on Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. Georgia Tech won 31 - 22. (Bob Andres for the Atlanta Journal Constitution)
Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets head coach Brent Key celebrates after beating Syracuse, 31-22, in Atlanta on Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (Bob Andres for the Atlanta Journal Constitution)
Georgia Tech players celebrate after beating Syracuse, 31-22, in Atlanta on Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (Bob Andres for the Atlanta Journal Constitution)
Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets head coach Brent Key celebrates after beating Syracuse, 31-22, in Atlanta on Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (Bob Andres for the Atlanta Journal Constitution)

Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets running back Jamal Haynes (11) has the ball stripped after a nice run and fumbles during the second half of an NCAA college football game between Georgia Tech and Syracuse in Atlanta on Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. Georgia Tech won, 31 - 22. (Bob Andres for the Atlanta Journal Constitution)

Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets linebacker Kyle Efford (44) and teammates celebrate after stopping Syracuse on fourth down during the second half of an NCAA college football game between Georgia Tech and Syracuse in Atlanta on Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. Georgia Tech won, 31 - 22. (Bob Andres for the Atlanta Journal Constitution)

Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets running back Jamal Haynes (11) celebrates after scoring on a touchdown run during the start of the second half of an NCAA college football game between Georgia Tech and Syracuse in Atlanta on Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets running back Jamal Haynes (11) rushes up the middle for a gain of 30 yards and a touchdown during the start of the second half of an NCAA college football game between Georgia Tech and Syracuse in Atlanta on Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. Georgia Tech won, 31 - 22. (Bob Andres for the Atlanta Journal Constitution)

On the second half kickoff, Syracuse Orange wide receiver Darrell Gill Jr. (82) fumbled, forced by Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets linebacker Paul Moala (13) and recovered by Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets linebacker Jacob Cruz (35) during an NCAA college football game between Georgia Tech and Syracuse in Atlanta on Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. Georgia Tech won, 31 - 22. (Bob Andres for the Atlanta Journal Constitution)

On the second half kickoff, Syracuse Orange wide receiver Darrell Gill Jr. (82) fumbled, forced by Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets linebacker Paul Moala (13) and recovered by Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets linebacker Jacob Cruz (35) during an NCAA college football game between Georgia Tech and Syracuse in Atlanta on Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. Georgia Tech won, 31 - 22. (Bob Andres for the Atlanta Journal Constitution)
Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets wide receiver Christian Leary (6) celebrates after the win. (Bob Andres for the Atlanta Journal Constitution)

Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets wide receiver Dominick Blaylock (12) runs for a touchdown after a catch during the first half of an NCAA college football game between Georgia Tech and Syracuse in Atlanta on Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. item.title: Photos: Georgia State is routed by LSU
item.description: Photos from the Georgia State at LSU college football game on Nov. 18, 2023. LSU won 56-14.

media:content.media:description: Georgia State quarterback Darren Grainger (3) is surrounded by LSU defenders as he attempts a run during the first half of an NCAA college football game in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. LSU won 56-14. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)

Georgia State running back Marcus Carroll (23) breaks free for a long touchdown run during the first half of an NCAA college football game against LSU in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)

Georgia State quarterback Darren Grainger, center front, reacts after his team turned the ball over on downs with an incomplete pass on fourth down against LSU during the first half of an NCAA college football game in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)

Georgia State quarterback Darren Grainger (3) throws to tight end Ahmon Green (85) during the first half of an NCAA college football game against LSU in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)
Georgia State head coach Shawn Elliott, center, reacts during the first half of an NCAA college football game against LSU in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)

Georgia State wide receiver Ja'Cyais Credle (8) tries to catch the ball against LSU safety Javien Toviano (25) during the first half of an NCAA college football game in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. Credle dropped the ball out of bounds. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)

LSU quarterback Jayden Daniels (5) runs against Georgia State linebacker Jontrey Hunter (1) during the first half of an NCAA college football game in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)

Georgia State quarterback Darren Grainger looks to throw the ball during the first half of an NCAA college football game against LSU in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)
LSU head coach Brian Kelly, right, reacts during the first half of an NCAA college football game against Georgia State in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)
Georgia State head coach Shawn Elliott throws before an NCAA college football game against LSU in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)
Georgia State quarterback Darren Grainger warms up before an NCAA college football game against LSU in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)
LSU quarterback Jayden Daniels warms up during an NCAA college football game against Georgia State in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)
LSU's Kyren Lacey scores a touchdown against Georgia State during an NCAA college football game in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (Scott Clause/The Daily Advertiser via AP)
LSU quarterback Jayden Daniels (5) throws during the first half of an NCAA college football game against Georgia State in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)

LSU wide receiver Kyren Lacy (2) goes out of bounds after a reception and a gain against Georgia State cornerback Ronald Cooper (24) during the first half of an NCAA college football game in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)
LSU quarterback Jayden Daniels (5) runs during the first half of an NCAA college football game against Georgia State in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)

Georgia State running back Marcus Carroll, right, celebrates after his touchdown with wide receiver Tailique Williams, left, during the first half of an NCAA college football game against LSU in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)

LSU wide receiver Kyren Lacy (2) scores a touchdown against Georgia State safety Jeremiah Johnson (6) as LSU wide receiver Malik Nabers (8) celebrates during the first half of an NCAA college football game in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)

LSU quarterback Jayden Daniels (5) scores a touchdown against Georgia State linebacker Jontrey Hunter (1) during the first half of an NCAA college football game in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)

LSU wide receiver Malik Nabers (8) grabs a reception that he finished with a touchdown against Georgia State cornerback Bryquice Brown (5) during the first half of an NCAA college football game in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)

LSU wide receiver Malik Nabers (8) scores a touchdown against Georgia State cornerback Bryquice Brown, right, during the first half of an NCAA college football game in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)

Georgia State wide receiver Tailique Williams (16) scores a touchdown against LSU linebacker Greg Penn III (30) during the first half of an NCAA college football game in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)

LSU wide receiver Malik Nabers (8) celebrates after his touchdown with quarterback Jayden Daniels (5) during the first half of an NCAA college football game against Georgia State in Baton Rouge, La., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023. (AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)

item.title: Photos: Bulldogs dominate Vols, improve to 11-0
item.description: AJC photos from the Georgia at Tennessee game on Nov. 18, 2023. The Bulldogs won 38-10.

media:content.media:description: Georgia quarterback Carson Beck (15) celebrates a touchdown pass to Georgia tight end Brock Bowers (not pictured) during the first quarter against the Tennessee at Neyland Stadium, Saturday, November 18, 2023, in Knoxville, Tn. The Bulldogs won 38-10. (Jason Getz / Jason.Getz@ajc.com)

Georgia head coach Kirby Smart tips his cap (right) as he and his players leave Neyland Stadium with a 38-10 victory over Tennessee in a NCAA college football game on Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023, in Knoxville. Curtis Compton for the Atlanta Journal Constitution

Georgia head coach Kirby Smart celebrates with Georgia Athletic Director Josh Brooks after Georgia’s win against Tennessee at Neyland Stadium, Saturday, November 18, 2023, in Knoxville, Tn. Georgia won 38-10. (Jason Getz / Jason.Getz@ajc.com)

Georgia defensive lineman Mykel Williams (13) sacks Tennessee quarterback Joe Milton III (7) during the third quarter at Neyland Stadium, Saturday, November 18, 2023, in Knoxville, Tn. Georgia won 38-10. (Jason Getz / Jason.Getz@ajc.com)

item.title: Photos: The scene at the Georgia vs. Tennessee game
item.description: AJC photos from the scene of the Georgia at Tennessee game in Knoxville on Nov. 18, 2023.

item.title: Flashback Photos: Atlanta's old Hotel Row
item.description: Once a prime area for railway travelers seeking lodging in 19th century Atlanta, the old Mitchell Street area has fallen on hard times.

media:content.media:description: Terminal Station in 1907. Hotel Row was originally built to serve its passengers' needs. HISTORIC ATLANTA GUIDEBOOK IMAGES / GSU ARCHIVES

The Hotel Row area of Mitchell Street in 1970. The City of Atlanta website describes Hotel Row as "a single block of commercial buildings, primarily hotels, originally built to serve the needs of passengers from the main railroad station in Atlanta, Terminal Station. The buildings are the most intact row of typical early 20th century commercial structures which once formed Atlanta's original business district and include Concordia Hall, the Gordon Hotel, the Scoville, the Sylvan and 2 commercial structures." TOM COFFIN PHOTOS / GSU ARCHIVES
The Terminal Hotel in 1907. HISTORIC ATLANTA GUIDEBOOK IMAGES / GSU ARCHIVES
May 8, 1908 -- Firemen putting out fire at the Terminal Hotel, located on Terminal Block. AJC PHOTO ARCHIVES

Original caption: "The Terminal district fire of May 8, 1908, left a square block of ruins. It consumed the buildings in the block bounded by Madison Avenue (Spring Street), Mitchell, Nelson and South Forsyth Streets. This picture was taken from the roof of Terminal Station. The Southern Railway Buildings had not yet been built. The Gholstin-Cunningham Spring Bed Company, right rear, across Nelson Street, was a forerunner of the Southern Spring Bed Company. The fire loss amounted to $1,250,000 and a total of 42 firms in 31 buildings were burned out." AJC PHOTO ARCHIVES
Jan. 5, 1979 -- The corner of Mitchell and Forsyth Streets, looking towards the State Capitol (right).
Friedman's Shoe Store on Mitchell Street, 1980s. Shown above are Bruce Teiehaber and sons Dean (left) and Randy (center). RON BELL / AJC FILE
March 1970 -- The front of the old Sylvan Hotel at 233-235 Mitchell Street. TOM COFFIN PHOTOGRAPHS / GSU ARCHIVES
1989 -- The Concordia Hall retail shops along Mitchell Street on the old Hotel Row. FLOYD JILLSON / AJC FILE

item.title: The Thanksgiving Shift
item.description: Image from the 2023 edition of holiday heroes

media:content.media:description: Jessica Bullock, a nurse in the newborn intensive care unit at Children’s Egleston Hospital cares for a newborn on Wednesday, Oct. 18, 2023. (Natrice Miller/ Natrice.miller@ajc.com)

Newly promoted Assistant Director of Nursing, Olivia Blackburn, chats with resident Ethel Williams during lunch at the A. G. Rhodes Wesley Woods facility in Decatur.She has worked holidays for five years, Thanksgivings and Christmases, as her family gathers back at home. She does it because she values her mission of connecting with the nursing home residents, who may or may not have family come to visit them. Greeting them with a human touch and saying their name can light up their face, she says. PHIL SKINNER FOR THE ATLANTA JOURNAL-CONSTITUTION

item.title: PHOTOS: Opponents protest public safety training center
item.description: After a weekend of protest training, opponents of Atlanta’s public safety training center began marching Monday morning from Gresham Park Recreation Center to the site where the $90 million facility is under construction in what organizers are calling a non-violent “Day of Action.”

media:content.media:description: Protestors demonstrating against Atlanta’s public training safety center march from Gresham Park in Atlanta on Monday, November 13, 2023. (Arvin Temkar / arvin.temkar@ajc.com)

Belkis Teran, mother of activist Manuel “Tortuguita” Teran, speaks to protesters gathered Monday, Nov. 13, 2023, to march against Atlanta's planned police and firefighter safety training center in an event organizers are calling a non-violent "Day of Action." Tortuguita was shot and killed by Georgia State Patrol troopers in January near near the site of training center during a "clearing operation." (Riley Bunch / Riley.Bunch@ajc.com)
Protestors demonstrating against Atlanta’s public training safety center march from Gresham Park in Atlanta on Monday, November 13, 2023. (Arvin Temkar / arvin.temkar@ajc.com)

Joel Paez, father of Manuel Esteban Paez Teran, also known as Tortuguita, kneels during a Native American drum circle at Gresham Park in Atlanta on Monday, November 13, 2023. Activists were preparing to demonstrate against Atlanta’s public training safety center gather (Arvin Temkar / arvin.temkar@ajc.com)
Protestors demonstrating against Atlanta’s public training safety center gather at Gresham Park in Atlanta on Monday, November 13, 2023. (Arvin Temkar / arvin.temkar@ajc.com)
Protestors demonstrating against Atlanta’s public training safety center march from Gresham Park in Atlanta on Monday, November 13, 2023. (Arvin Temkar / arvin.temkar@ajc.com)

Protestors demonstrating against Atlanta’s public training safety center gather at Gresham Park in Atlanta on Monday, November 13, 2023. The number for a jail support line is written on the hand of an activist. (Arvin Temkar / arvin.temkar@ajc.com)

Belkis Terán, mother of Manuel Esteban Paez Teran, also known as Tortuguita, speaks to protestors at Gresham Park in Atlanta on Monday, November 13, 2023. The activists were preparing to demonstrate against Atlanta’s public training safety center gather (Arvin Temkar / arvin.temkar@ajc.com)
Protestors demonstrating against Atlanta’s public training safety center gather at Gresham Park in Atlanta on Monday, November 13, 2023. (Arvin Temkar / arvin.temkar@ajc.com)
Police and protesters clash at march on Atlanta's police and firefighters safety training center on Monday, Nov. 13, 2023. (Riley Bunch / Riley.Bunch@ajc.com)
Police stand by after a clash with protestors demonstrating against Atlanta’s public training safety center in Atlanta on Monday, November 13, 2023. (Arvin Temkar / arvin.temkar@ajc.com)
Protestors demonstrating against Atlanta’s public training safety center flee after police deploy tear gas in Atlanta on Monday, November 13, 2023. (Arvin Temkar / arvin.temkar@ajc.com)
Protestors demonstrating against Atlanta’s public training safety center clash with police in Atlanta on Monday, November 13, 2023. (Arvin Temkar / arvin.temkar@ajc.com)

November 13, 2023 Atlanta: The showdown between protesters and police occurred on Constitution Road. After a weekend of protest training, opponents of Atlanta’s public safety training center began marching Monday morning from Gresham Park Recreation Center to the site where the $90 million facility is under construction in what organizers are calling a non-violent “Day of Action.” A few hundred people participated in the march, most wearing masks and many donned in plastic painters suits. City officials say the new center is necessary to provide world-class training to its officers and firefighters, which are currently using outdated facilities. Opponents say it will be used to further militarize police and construction will destroy swaths of one of the largest urban forests in the country. (John Spink / John.Spink@ajc.com)

November 13, 2023 Atlanta: The showdown between protesters and police occurred on Constitution Road. After a weekend of protest training, opponents of Atlanta’s public safety training center began marching Monday morning from Gresham Park Recreation Center to the site where the $90 million facility is under construction in what organizers are calling a non-violent “Day of Action.” A few hundred people participated in the march, most wearing masks and many donned in plastic painters suits. City officials say the new center is necessary to provide world-class training to its officers and firefighters, which are currently using outdated facilities. Opponents say it will be used to further militarize police and construction will destroy swaths of one of the largest urban forests in the country. (John Spink / John.Spink@ajc.com)

November 13, 2023 Atlanta: The showdown between protesters and police occurred on Constitution Road. After a weekend of protest training, opponents of Atlanta’s public safety training center began marching Monday morning from Gresham Park Recreation Center to the site where the $90 million facility is under construction in what organizers are calling a non-violent “Day of Action.” A few hundred people participated in the march, most wearing masks and many donned in plastic painters suits. City officials say the new center is necessary to provide world-class training to its officers and firefighters, which are currently using outdated facilities. Opponents say it will be used to further militarize police and construction will destroy swaths of one of the largest urban forests in the country. (John Spink / John.Spink@ajc.com)

City officials say the new center is necessary to provide world-class training to its officers and firefighters, which are currently using outdated facilities. Opponents say it will be used to further militarize police and construction will destroy swaths of one of the largest urban forests in the country. (John Spink / John.Spink@ajc.com)

item.title: Photos: Georgia Tech routed by Clemson

item.title: PHOTOS: 42nd annual Georgia Veterans Day Parade
item.description: People brave the rainy weather to honor those who have served our country during the 42nd annual Georgia Veterans Day Parade in Atlanta.

media:content.media:description: A color guard waits for the beginning of the 42nd annual Georgia Veterans Day Parade in Midtown Atlanta on Saturday, Nov. 11, 2023. (Ben Gray / Ben@BenGray.com)

Manzur waits patiently for the start of the 42nd annual Georgia Veterans Day Parade in Midtown Atlanta on Saturday, Nov. 11, 2023. He is wearing an outfit custom made from his owner Cpl. Josh Bailey’s Marine Corps dress uniform. (Ben Gray / Ben@BenGray.com)

item.title: PHOTOS: Photos of the Month -- October
item.description: October images in metro Atlanta reflect pride, football, protests and portraits.

media:content.media:description: October 11, 2023 Atlanta: A large fire engulfed three homes in a northwest Atlanta neighborhood Wednesday morning, Oct. 11, 2023 officials said. Crews with Atlanta fire responded around 6:20 a.m. to a structure fire in the 600 block of Tazor Street, according to Battalion Chief Derek Hullender. At the scene, one house was completed destroyed and the fire had already spread to two neighboring homes. (John Spink / John.Spink@ajc.com)
Aliyah Bradley-Davino, who identifies as demifluid, participates in the annual Pride Parade along Peachtree Street on Sunday, Oct. 15, 2023. (Jenni Girtman for The Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

North Carolina Tar Heels running back Omarion Hampton (28) leaps over Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets defensive back Myles Sims (0) during the second half of an NCAA football game In Atlanta on Saturday, Oct. 28, 2023 between the Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets and the North Carolina Tar Heels. Georgia Tech won, 46-42. (Bob Andres for the Atlanta Journal Constitution)

View of Yellow Jacket Shoals in the Flint River from a private property, Thursday, October 19, 2023, in Thomaston. A legal battle over property rights and fishing on the Flint River could have implications for public access to waterways across the state. Recently, two property owners directly across from each other on the Flint River in Upson County and Talbot County, about two hours south of Atlanta, have sued the state to block the public from fishing the shoals that lie between them. (Hyosub Shin / Hyosub.Shin@ajc.com)

Thousands of Israel supporters, including Rachel Domba, left, and Shiri Tzuk, right, with her children Naama Tzuk and Nora Tzuk, gather inside and outside of City Springs in Sandy Spring on Tuesday, Oct 10, 2023 for a rally for Israel. (Jenni Girtman for The Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

Pro-Palestinian supporters hold signs during a pro-Palestinian rally in front of the CNN Center, Friday, October 20, 2023, in Atlanta. Hundreds of people are gathering in Downtown Atlanta as they rally and march in support of Palestine.(Hyosub Shin / Hyosub.Shin@ajc.com)

Former day care owner Amanda Hickey gives a statement at DeKalb County Courthouse in Decatur on Friday, October 13, 2023. Hickey was sentenced to 30 years in prison Friday in the death of a 4-month-old boy and the abuse of six other children in her care. (Arvin Temkar / arvin.temkar@ajc.com)
Fulton County Animal Services Field Service Supervisor Ladream Taylor tries to tempt an injured stray dog with a treat Thursday, Oct. 5, 2023 in Northwest Atlanta. (Ben Gray / Ben@BenGray.com)
Sen. Rev. Raphael Warnock talks with Lee Nunn while touring his farm in Madison on Wednesday, Oct. 11, 2023.ÊÊÊ(Ben Gray / Ben@BenGray.com)
The annual Pride Parade runs up Peachtree Street to 10th Street and into Piedmont Park on Sunday, Oct 15, 2023. (Jenni Girtman for The Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

Rapper and record executive Gucci Mane hit the stage in front of an energetic crowd on the same day he released his new album "Breath Fresh Air" at The Tabernacle on Tuesday, October 17, 2023, in Atlanta. Miguel Martinez /miguel.martinezjimenez@ajc.com

Minnesota Timberwolves center Karl-Anthony Towns (32) makes a jump over the Hawks’ defense during the second half of an NBA game Monday, October 30, 2023 at State Farm Arena. (Daniel Varnado/For the AJC)

Sefika Dizdarevic, from Bosnia and Herzegovina, can’t hold back her joy as she is sworn in as a naturalized citizen during a ceremony at The Carter Center in Atlanta on Sunday, Oct. 1, 2023. October 19, 2023 FULTON COUNTY: Here firefighters from several metro jurisdictions train at the Knights Inn located at 4253 Shirley Drive SW. The Atlanta Regional Commission’s Homeland Security & Emergency Preparedness Department first-ever Atlanta Regional Full-Scale Emergency Training Exercise was held on Thursday, Oct. 19, 2023 on Fulton Industrial Boulevard at two nearby locations. Emergency responders from the City of Atlanta and five metro Atlanta counties – Clayton, Cobb, DeKalb, Fulton, and Gwinnett all jointly participated in the daylong event Daylong that simulated a terrorist attack on a hotel. Firefighters trained at the Knights Inn located at 4253 Shirley Drive SW and the police at the Red Roof Inn 4430 Frederick Drive SW. Police and fire vehicles, SWAT teams, Hazardous materials crews, Search & rescue teams and Victim triage were all on hand during the event which saw 50-victim volunteers in realistic disaster scenarios and scenes. (John Spink / John.Spink@ajc.com)

A member of the F-22 Demo Team inspects the jet after landing at Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport on Thursday, October 5, 2023. October 24, 2023 Atlanta: Douglas County Sheriff investigators gathered on North Bear Drive after a Douglas County sheriff’s deputy survived a shooting Wednesday morning, Oct. 25, 2023 but was rushed to the hospital for his injuries, officials said. Few details have been released, but Douglas sheriff’s office spokesman Capt. Trent Wilson confirmed that a deputy had been shot. Sheriff Tim Pounds posted a message of reassurance to the community, acknowledging the shooting near Kings Highway. “The situation is under control and there is no current threat to the community or the nearby school,” Pounds said. The GBI is responding to the scene, where investigators were seen in photos surrounding a pickup truck on North Bear Drive, a residential street off Kings Highway just south of Yeager Middle School, Channel 2 Action News reported. The WSB 24-hour Traffic Center also reported police activity on Bill Arp Road south of I-20. Yeager, Alexander High School and Bill Arp Elementary were all placed on lockdown Wednesday morning, but that has since been lifted, Douglas County Schools spokeswoman Portia Lake told The Atlanta Journal-Constitution. Video was captured of Douglas sheriff’s deputies and Georgia State Patrol vehicles escorting an ambulance to Grady Memorial Hospital. No further information has been released about the incident. Officials did not say if a suspect had been taken into custody. (John Spink / John.Spink@ajc.com)

October 23, 2023 Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport: Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport has closed its popular South economy lot on Monday, Oct. 23, 2023 for a construction project, removing about 3,000 parking spaces from use next to the domestic terminal. The airport is advising travelers to use park-ride lots as an alternative, including the ATL West deck connected to the terminal via SkyTrain and the ATL Select lot. The airport has said it would add staff to Òaddress public concernsÓ and signs to direct motorists. Other options for travelers include off-airport parking lots that offer shuttle service to the terminal, MARTA, taxis and rideshare services, including Uber and Lyft. Those planning to park at the airport for trips should consider making an advance parking reservation. The airport offers online reservations for its ATL West deck, ATL Select lot and international parking decks. Many off-airport lots also offer parking reservations. The North economy lot is still in use, but was already full by Monday morning when the South economy lot closed, according to the airportÕs website, which lists parking lot status. Even before MondayÕs closure of the South economy lot, airport parking decks and lots often reached capacity during busy periods, forcing motorists to drive around the airport searching for other lots and spaces while rushing to catch their flights. Hartsfield-Jackson is closing the South economy lot to build a new parking deck on the site. The new seven-level deck will have 6,700 parking spaces and updated technology including digital parking space availability indicators and ticketless entry and exit. It will take three years to build, and is part of a decade-long parking construction project that started last year. After the new parking deck is completed on the site of the South economy lot in late 2026, a phased construction project will begin to demolish and reconstruct the existing South and North decks next to the domestic terminal. Those aging decks were originally built in 1980. (John Spink / John.Spink@ajc.com)

October 20, 2023 Atlanta: Neville Francis walks by the standing water along Martin Luther King Jr. Drive near Centennial Olympic Park Drive in downtown Atlanta on Friday, Oct. 20, 2023 as scattered showers and some isolated thunderstorms moved across metro. It’s much-needed moisture. “October is typically our driest month of the year. This year has held true to form,” Channel 2 Action News meteorologist Brian Monahan said. “We are about half an inch or so below average so far for the month of October, and for a month that’s already on the drier side, a little bit of rain helps. A cold front passed over the region, bringing in dryer air with it and setting us up for a “beautiful fall weekend,” Monahan said. On Saturday, temperatures will climb up to the mid 70s with mostly sunny skies. Similar conditions are in store for Sunday, though it might be just a touch cooler with a projected high back in the low 70s. The mild and sunny trend will stick around at least for the first half of next week. (John Spink / John.Spink@ajc.com)

October 19, 2023 FULTON COUNTY: Here firefighters from several metro jurisdictions train at the Knights Inn located at 4253 Shirley Drive SW. The Atlanta Regional Commission’s Homeland Security & Emergency Preparedness Department first-ever Atlanta Regional Full-Scale Emergency Training Exercise was held on Thursday, Oct. 19, 2023 on Fulton Industrial Boulevard at two nearby locations. Emergency responders from the City of Atlanta and five metro Atlanta counties – Clayton, Cobb, DeKalb, Fulton, and Gwinnett all jointly participated in the daylong event Daylong that simulated a terrorist attack on a hotel. Firefighters trained at the Knights Inn located at 4253 Shirley Drive SW and the police at the Red Roof Inn 4430 Frederick Drive SW. Police and fire vehicles, SWAT teams, Hazardous materials crews, Search & rescue teams and Victim triage were all on hand during the event which saw 50-victim volunteers in realistic disaster scenarios and scenes. (John Spink / John.Spink@ajc.com)

October 11, 2023 Atlanta: A crashed plane remained on the scene Wednesday late morning Oct. 11, 2023 as Clayton County authorities are working to remove it after it crashed into a wooded area behind a neighborhood and left two women injured just before midnight Tuesday. Police said they received a distress call from the fixed-wing, single-engine aircraft around 11:55 p.m., letting them know it was running out of fuel. It took officers more than an hour to find the crash site off Tara Beach Lane in the Tara Beach Estates subdivision just outside Irondale, officials said. The four-seater was found upside down and suspended in a small tree. The women had already escaped the wreckage and were found on the ground in the woods. They were taken to a hospital with injuries that weren’t considered life-threatening, according to police. Officials are still working to remove the plane and have asked people to avoid the area. The Federal Aviation Administration and the National Transportation Safety Board have taken over the investigation. It is not clear from where it took off or where it was headed, as its owner opted out of public flight tracking. (John Spink / John.Spink@ajc.com)

October 9, 2023 Atlanta: Theo Beck rode her bike past a pair of skeletons sitting in the 900 block of Springdale Road in Atlanta on Monday, Oct. 9, 2023 that started off on the cold side but warmed back up to near-normal temperatures. Channel 2 Action News meteorologist Eboni Deon said Tuesday will get a bit warmer than normal, with a projected high of 81 degrees in the city. The warmer weather is expected to stay with us through most of the week. There is still no rain in the forecast for Tuesday. The next chance of showers comes on Wednesday. It’ll start off sunny that day, but clouds will build in later in the day and bring some tropical moisture from the southwest, Deon said. Heavier rain should hold off until Thursday morning and is expected to stay mostly to the south of the city. (John Spink / John.Spink@ajc.com)
